Award.AwardTitle: TCS Academic Leadership Graduate Certificate Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chicago School of Professional Psychology will build upon its existing offerings to develop and deliver a specialized focus in Academic Leadership, designed to address the compelling need for women faculty in the STEM disciplines at HBCUs to acquire leadership skills. The program will serve three cohorts of 15 participants each, each of whom will receive a Graduate Certificate in Academic Leadership.

Broader Impact
With the focus of this project on women STEM faculty in Historically African-American Colleges and Universities, this project will contribute significantly to increasing gender diversity in the leadership ranks at these institutions. By supporting women of color in STEM fields in realizing their leadership potential, this program will help ensure that students and faculty in these disciplines will benefit from the skills, wisdom, breadth of experience and unique perspectives that such women will provide. The model designed for the TCSPP Academic Leadership Graduate Certificate Program has promise for broad dissemination across its eastcoast, midwest, and westcoast campuses and their wide professional networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With generous funding from the National Science Foundation, a one-year, intensive Post-Graduate Certificate Program in Academic Leadership launched in May 2013 at The Chicago School of Professional Psychology (NSF Award #1217427) to address both the national need to attract more women to the STEM workforce and the related need to provide female role models in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines for the large percentage of female students matriculating on the campuses of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). Both of these objectives are essential for the United States to retain its global leadership in the STEM fields.

The overarching goal of the program was to prepare and position the next generation of STEM women faculty and emerging leaders to ascend to academic leadership roles on their campuses, either within their STEM disciplines or elsewhere in the academic leadership structure. The program was later expanded to include Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs) and continued at The Chicago School through July 2016. The program was transferred to Fielding Graduate University (NSF Award #1651417) in August 2016 based on this institution's deep commitment to issues of diversity, service, and innovation. The curriculum was transformed to better support the unique needs of the Tribal College community. The program was sustained at Fielding until the end of the funding period.

Referred to as Opportunities for UnderRepresented Scholars (OURS), this program provided online-blended instruction on critical topics relevant to current and future leadership in higher education in general and at HBCUs & TCUs in particular. The program also provided periodic face-to-face residencies around the country and mentored Action Learning Projects on the fellows' home campuses. Leadership assessments and feedback were explicitly implemented to advance the program fellows' professional development by improving their emotional intelligence skillset. Their professional growth was further directed and encouraged through mentorship by an experienced female academic leader who provided individualized career coaching over the entire program year. The program also afforded fellows with the ability to engage directly with senior officials at various government agencies who clarified the areas within their departments that impact both HBCUs and TCUs, as well as the numerous funding programs & activities available to these specific institutions.

Since inception, the OURS program has trained a total of 53 STEM women faculty and emerging leaders (41 from HBCUs and 12 from TCUs). The program also built and strengthened a network of leaders within these two academic communities who are able to develop cross-cultural relationships to support each other through their career trajectories. Numerous accomplishments have been realized through this program. A number of STEM faculty fellows have been promoted to senior leadership positions both within and outside of their respective institutions including the roles of Executive Director, Department Chair, Dean and Provost. Although it was not a direct goal of the program, evaluation data revealed that participation in the program motivated many fellows to seek and receive promotion to full professor at their institutions (with more promotions under review). Several of the fellows' Action Learning Projects were implemented institution-wide, with one published in the Tribal College and University Research Journal. The first cohort of program fellows published a unique collection of their individual stories in the book Women Called to Lead: Empowering Women of Color in Academic Leadership. The goal of this book is to support the preparation of women in their journey to becoming a leader in higher education by providing both leadership theory and practice, as well as highlighting a range of tangible solutions for the leadership challenges faced by women of color in the STEM disciplines. The development of a second book is currently underway to address the impact that women of color in the STEM disciplines have made at Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) with regard to leadership, the path to obtain full professor rank & senior leadership positions and campus transformation initiatives led by women of color that have changed the landscape of their institutions.

For specific questions or comments about this program and/or the information included in this NSF Project Outcomes Report, please contact the NSF/OURS Program Director by email at mewynn@fielding.edu.
